title: Syria’s new leaders dissolve rebel factions, merge them under Defense Ministry
description: Ahmed al-Sharaa, Syria’s de facto leader, said he wants post-Assad Syria to be “united.” Gaza’s Health Ministry said Israeli forces targeted three hospitals.
author: Kareem Fahim, Vivian Ho, Frances Vinall, Lior Soroka, Bryan Pietsch
byline: Kareem Fahim, Vivian Ho, Frances Vinall, Lior Soroka, Bryan Pietsch, Mohamad El Chamaa, Evan Hill, Miriam Berger, Loveday Morris, Suzan Haidamous, Leo Sands
excerpt: Ahmed al-Sharaa, Syria’s de facto leader, said he wants post-Assad Syria to be “united.” Gaza’s Health Ministry said Israeli forces targeted three hospitals.
text: DAMASCUS — Syrian interim leader Ahmed al-Sharaa and the heads of rebel factions agreed Tuesday to merge the groups under the Ministry of Defense, according to a statement from Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), the Islamist rebel group that led the charge to topple dictator Bashar al-Assad.The statement did not specify which groups were included in the agreement. A spokesman for HTS said only that there was “no faction that did not agree.”
html:
DAMASCUS — Syrian interim leader Ahmed al-Sharaa and the heads of rebel factions agreed Tuesday to merge the groups under the Ministry of Defense, according to a statement from Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), the Islamist rebel group that led the charge to topple dictator Bashar al-Assad.

The statement did not specify which groups were included in the agreement. A spokesman for HTS said only that there was “no faction that did not agree.”
